Situation1: The meeting will cover key project updates that won’t be summarized elsewhere.
Situation2: They interact warmly with a long line of shoppers during a busy lunch hour.
Story: I glanced at the clock above the register—12:55 p.m. The lunch rush was in full swing, and the line of customers snaked past the bakery display. My manager had just reminded me to keep things moving and greet everyone with a smile. I tried to focus on scanning groceries and making small talk, but my mind kept drifting to the team meeting scheduled for 1:00 p.m. in the break room. My colleagues expected me there; the agenda included crucial project updates that wouldn’t be shared later. I could already imagine the disappointed looks if I missed it, the subtle sense of being left out. But right now, I was the only cashier on duty, and the customers were growing impatient. I felt the pressure mounting from both sides—my team counting on my input, my manager and customers needing my attention here. My heart pounded as I handed a receipt to the next shopper, torn between slipping away to the meeting and staying at my post, knowing I couldn’t be in both places at once.
